name: To Kill a Mockingbird
descip: A powerful exploration of racism and injustice in the American South.                    --Harper lee

name: Pride and Prejudice
descip: A classic romance novel that also delves into themes of class and society.               -- Jane Austen

name: The Great Gatsby
descip: A novel set in the Jazz Age that explores themes of wealth, love, and the American Dream.               -- F. Scott Fitzgerald

name: Crime and Punishment
descip: A psychological novel that delves into the mind of a troubled protagonist.           --Fyodor Dostoevsky
A dystopian novel that explores the dangers of totalitarianism and surveillance.             --George Orwell

name: Moby-Dick
descip: An epic tale of obsession and revenge set against the backdrop of whaling.               --Herman Melville

name: The Catcher in the Rye
descip: A coming-of-age story featuring the iconic character Holden Caulfield.               --J.D. Salinger

name: One Hundred Years of Solitude
descip: A masterpiece of magical realism that tells the story of the Buendía family.                 --Gabriel García Márquez

name: Brave New World
descip: A dystopian novel that explores the consequences of a highly controlled society.             --Aldous Huxley

name: Jane Eyre
descip: A classic Gothic novel featuring a strong-willed heroine.            --Charlotte Brontë

name: The Lord of the Rings
descip: A fantasy epic that transports readers to the world of Middle-earth.                 --J.R.R. Tolkien

name: The Odyssey
descip: An ancient Greek epic poem that tells the adventures of Odysseus.                        --Homer

name: The Brothers Karamazov
descip: A philosophical novel that examines faith, morality, and family.                 --Fyodor Dostoevsky

name: The Picture of Dorian Gray
descip: A novel that explores themes of vanity and the consequences of a hedonistic lifestyle.                   -- Oscar Wilde

name: Frankenstein
descip: The classic Gothic tale of the scientist Victor Frankenstein and his monstrous creation.                 --Mary Shelley

name: Don Quixote
descip: Often considered the first modern novel, it follows the adventures of a delusional knight.               --Miguel de Cervantes

name: War and Peace
descip: An epic novel that chronicles the lives of Russian aristocrats during the Napoleonic Wars.               --Leo Tolstoy

name: Wuthering Heights
descip: A dark and passionate novel of love and revenge on the Yorkshire moors.              --Emily Brontë

name: The Handmaid's Tale
descip: A dystopian novel that explores themes of women's rights and authoritarianism.               --Margaret Atwood

name: The Kite Runner
descip: A gripping novel that explores themes of friendship, betrayal, and redemption against the backdrop of Afghanistan's tumultuous history.              --Khaled Hosseini

name: The Road
descip: A post-apocalyptic novel that follows a father and son's journey through a desolate landscape.                   --Cormac McCarthy

name: The Alchemist
descip: A philosophical novel that explores the pursuit of one's dreams and personal legend.             --Paulo Coelho

name: The Book Thief
descip: A novel narrated by Death and centered around a young girl's experiences in Nazi Germany.                --Markus Zusak

name: The Goldfinch
descip: A Pulitzer Prize-winning novel that follows a young man's life after a tragic event at an art museum.                --Donna Tartt

name: Beloved
descip: A novel that delves into the haunting legacy of slavery and its impact on a mother and her children.                 --Toni Morrison

name: Life of Pi
descip: A philosophical and allegorical novel about a young boy's survival on a lifeboat with a Bengal tiger.            --Yann Martel

name: The Nightingale
descip: A historical novel set in Nazi-occupied France, focusing on the bravery and sacrifices of two sisters.               --Kristin Hannah

name: All the Light We Cannot See
descip: A Pulitzer Prize-winning novel that weaves together the stories of a blind French girl and a German boy during World War II.         --Anthony Doerr

name: Middlemarch
descip: A classic Victorian novel that delves into the lives and relationships of residents in a small English town.                 --George Eliot

name: The Grapes of Wrath
descip: A powerful novel that explores the struggles of the Joad family during the Great Depression.         --John Steinbeck

name: A Tale of Two Cities
descip: Set during the French Revolution, this novel explores themes of resurrection and sacrifice.              --Charles Dickens

name: The Scarlet Letter
descip: A classic novel about sin, guilt, and redemption in 17th-century Puritan Massachusetts.          --Nathaniel Hawthorne

name: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest
descip: A novel set in a mental hospital, exploring themes of individuality and authority.               --Ken Kesey

name: the count of monte cristo
descip: A gripping tale of revenge and redemption.               ---Alexandre Dumas

name: The night circus
descip: A magical and atmospheric novel about a mystical competition between two young magicians.            --Erin Morgenstern

name: the Girl with the dragon tattoo
descip: A gripping mystery novel featuring investigative journalist Mikael Blomkvist and hacker Lisbeth Salander.            --Stieg Larsson

name: the martian
descip: A science fiction novel about an astronaut's struggle to survive alone on Mars.              --Andy Weir

name: the sympathizer
descip: A Pulitzer Prize-winning novel that explores the experiences of a Vietnamese communist spy during and after the Vietnam War.             --Viet Thanh Nguyen

name: the shadow of the wind
descip: A mystery novel set in post-war Barcelona that revolves around a hidden library of forgotten books.          --Carlos Ruiz Zafón

name: the wind-up bird Chronicle
descip: A surreal and philosophical novel that blurs the lines between reality and fantasy.          --Haruki Murakami

name: the secret history
descip: A psychological thriller set in an elite college, exploring themes of obsession and guilt.               --Donna Tartt

name: Gone with the Wind
descip: it vividly depicts the drama of the Civil War and Reconstruction. This is the tale of Scarlett O'Hara, the spoiled, manipulative daughter of a wealthy plantation owner, who arrives at young womanhood just in time to see the Civil War forever change her way of life        --Margaret Mitchell

name: The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe
descip: The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe is a portal fantasy novel for children    --- C. S. Lewis

name: Lord of the Flies
descip: the story of a group of boys who find themselves on an island after their plane crashes. With no adult supervision, some members of the group soon turn to savagery      William Golding

name: Animal Farm
descip: the story of farm animals that revolt against the farmer. Following the revolution, the pigs take power over the other animals and the farm begins to fall apart        George Orwell

name: Catch-22
descip: It centres on Captain John Yossarian, an American bombardier stationed on a Mediterranean island during World War II, and chronicles his desperate attempts to stay alive.        --Joseph Heller

name: A Clockwork Orange
descip: it is the first-person account of a juvenile delinquent who undergoes state-sponsored psychological rehabilitation for his aberrant behaviour.        --Anthony Burgess

name: Are You There God? It's Me, Margaret
descip: It's Me, Margaret  is a timeless coming-of-age novel that beautifully captures the essence of adolescence and the search for identity.    -- Judy Blume

name: Watchmen
descip: A dark and dystopian deconstruction of the superhero genre, the film is set in an alternate history in the year 1985 at the height of the Cold War, as a group of mostly retired American superheroes investigate the murder of one of their own.      --Alan Moore

name: Atonement
descip: It tells the story of Briony's false accusation of rape against her sister Cecilia's lover, Robbie. The couple are separated and Briony spends her life trying to atone for her mistake.        --Ian McEwan

name: Never Let Me Go
descip: the story of three friends who grow up in an enclosed environment, a kind of boarding school, only gradually coming to understand that, parentless and unable to have children themselves, they are not considered to be fully human like the people outside.      --Kazuo Ishiguro

name: Invisible Man
descip: Invisible Man is the story of a young, college-educated black man struggling to survive and succeed in a racially divided society that refuses to see him as a human being.      --Ralph Ellison

name: Mrs. Dalloway
descip: The novel addresses the nature of time in personal experience through multiple interwoven stories, particularly that of Clarissa as she prepares for and hosts a party and that of the mentally damaged war veteran Septimus Warren Smith.      --Virginia Woolf

name: On the Road
descip: The story follows Sal Paradise, a stand-in for Kerouac, as he travels across the United States and Mexico in search of better self-understanding and an understanding of the spiritual world.    --Jack Kerouac

name: The Sun Also Rises
descip: The story follows the flamboyant Brett and the hapless Jake as they journey from the wild nightlife of 1920s Paris to the brutal bullfighting rings of Spain with a motley group of expatriates. It is an age of moral bankruptcy, spiritual dissolution, unrealized love, and vanishing illusions.    --Ernest Hemingway.

name: The Big Sleep
descip: Philip Marlowe, a tough, cynical, yet honest private detective, is hired by the old, ailing General Sternwood to help him take care of Arthur Gwynn Geiger, a homosexual (possibly bisexual) pornographer who has been blackmailing the General with potentially scandalous pictures of the General's daughter.    --Raymond Chandler

name: Possession
descip: traces the lives of a pair of young academics as they uncover a clandestine relationship between two long-dead Victorian poets.      --A. S. Byatt

name: A Passage to India
descip: The novel examines racism and colonialism as well as a theme Forster developed in many earlier works, namely, the need to maintain both ties to the earth and a cerebral life of the imagination.    -- E.M. Forster

name: Their Eyes Were Watching God
descip: the journey of Janie Crawford as she searches for love, independence, and self-fulfillment in the Deep South during the early 20th century.    -- Zora Neale Hurston

name: The Sound and the Fury
descip: It  is about what happens to a formerly prestigious family as the 20th-century clashes with their values and perceptions.    --William Faulkner

name: All the King's Men
descip: The story concerns the rise and fall of Willie Stark, a character modeled on Huey Long, the governor of Louisiana during the time frame of the novel (late 1920s to early '30s).     -- Robert Penn Warren

name: The Blind Assassin
descip: The novel explores the complex relationships between two sisters, Iris and Laura, and the political and cultural changes of their time.    --Margaret Eleanor Atwood

name: Native Son
descip: It follows Bigger Thomas, a young Black man living in 1930s Chicago. It explores the systemic racism and oppression he faces.    --Richard Wright

name: Ragtime
descip: It centers around three families: a wealthy white family, a Black family, and a Jewish immigrant family. The story's main action centers around Black musician Walker Coalhouse seeking justice for the racist destruction of his car and his ultimate death at the hands of white authorities.    --E. L. Doctorow

name: Light in August
descip: Set in the author's present day, the interwar period, the novel centers on two strangers, a pregnant white woman and a man who passes as white but who believes himself to be of mixed ethnicity.    --William Faulkner

name: To the Lighthouse
descip: A story's theme is the message woven throughout it, often about important topics such as human nature, life, or society. It is deeper than the plot or summary and it can answer questions such as What does it mean to be a family? or What are we afraid of?.    --Adeline Virginia Woolf

name: The French Lieutenant's Woman
descip: The plot explores the fraught relationship of gentleman and amateur naturalist Charles Smithson and Sarah Woodruff, the former governess and independent woman with whom he falls in love.    --John Fowles

name: The Heart Is a Lonely Hunter
descip: Set in Georgia in the 1930s, the novel reflects the isolation, poverty, racism, and social upheaval that characterized that era. The story centers around a deaf-mute, John Singer, and the four individuals in the community who choose to confide in him.    --Carson McCullers

name: Naked Lunch
descip: Naked Lunch is a dark, wild ride through the terror of heroin addiction and withdrawal, filled with paranoia, erotica and drug-fueled hallucinations.     --William S. Burrough

name: Brideshead Revisited
descip: Brideshead Revisited, The Sacred & Profane Memories of Brideshead Revisited follows the aristocratic Flyte family from the 1920s through to the Second World War.    --Evelyn Waugh

name: Infinite Jest
descip: At the core of Infinite Jest is a story about addiction and the different ways that people find themselves hooked. Wallace's key argument is that to be human and alive is to be addicted to something, and the real power comes in choosing to what you might find yourself beholden.    --David Foster Wallace

name: Revolutionary Road
descip: Revolutionary Road is about many things: adultery, abortion, a failed marriage, and the emptiness of suburban consumer culture as the fulfillment of the American Dream.    --Richard Yates

name: Snow Crash
descip: Snow Crash (1992) is a cyberpunk sci-fi novel starring katana-wielding, pizza-delivering hacker Hiro Protagonist and his partner, spunky teen skateboarder Y.T. It features a virus called Snow Crash.    --Neal Stephenson,

name: Midnight's Children
descip: It is a historical chronicle of modern India centring on the inextricably linked fates of two children who were born within the first hour of independence from Great Britain.    --Salman Rushdie

name: The Prime of Miss Jean Brodie
descip: The character of Miss Jean Brodie was based in part on Christina Kay, a teacher of Spark's for two years at James Gillespie's School for Girls.    --Dame Muriel Sarah Spark

name: Death Comes for the Archbishop
descip: Death Comes for the Archbishop traces the friendship and adventures of Bishop Jean Latour and vicar Father Joseph Vaillant as they organize the new Roman Catholic diocese of New Mexico.    -- Willa Cather

name: American Pastoral
descip: American Pastoral takes a plunge into the depths of America's heart and soul and analyzes its curious multiculturalism, its unrestrained self-love and its misdirected self-hatred.    --Philip Roth

name: The Power and the Glory
descip: The novel follows the ,whiskey priest, the last practicing Catholic clergyman in the region, as he is pursued by authorities. Amidst moral ambiguity, the story explores redemption, faith, and human frailty.    --Henry Graham

name: Portnoys Complaint
descip: This comic novel is structured as a confession to a psychiatrist by Alexander Portnoy, who relates the details of his adolescent obsession with masturbation and his domination by his overly possessive mother, Sophie.  --Philip Roth

name: The Corrections
descip: The Corrections is a comic, tragic epic of worlds colliding: an old-fashioned world of civic virtue and sexual inhibitions, a new world of home surveillance, hands-off parenting, do-it-yourself mental health care.      -Jonathan Franzen

name: Gravitys Rainbow
descip: Gravity's Rainbow is set toward the end of World War II and features an American character who has a peculiar relationship with the V-2 rockets launched by the Germans.    -Thomas Pynchon

name: Under the Volcano
descip: The novel tells the story of Geoffrey Firmin, an alcoholic British consul in the Mexican city of Quauhnahuac, on the Day of the Dead in November 1938    --Malcolm Lowry

name: The Painted Bird
descip: story follows a dark-haired, olive-skinned boy, abandoned by his parents during World War II, as he wanders alone from one village to another, sometimes hounded and tortured, only rarely sheltered and cared for.    --Jerzy Kosiński

name: Go Tell It on the Mountain
descip: Go Tell It on the Mountain is a semi-autobiographical novel. It is loosely based on Baldwin's own childhood growing up in Harlem and his relationship with his religious and violent father.    --James Baldwin

name: A House for Mr Biswas
descip: It follows the life of Mr. Mohun Biswas, a protagonist inspired by Naipaul's father, as he struggles to find his freedom and a house of his own.    ---V. S. Naipaul

name: Play It As It Lays
descip: It depicts Hollywood as a broken paradise as seen from the point of view of a disenchanted actress, in contrast to the more common, utopian view of Hollywood.    ---joan Didion

name: Lucky Jim
descip: Lucky Jim (1954) is a comic novel by English author Kingsley Amis (1922-1995). Jim Dixon is a cynical history lecturer struggling to fit into the stuffy atmosphere of an unnamed English university. As Jim hopes for a spell of good luck, misfortunes continue to befall him.

name: Ubik
descip: Ubik hits the ground running with super sci-fi technology, and we’re introduced to several new innovations of this world. First up, companies employ telepaths and precogs (people who can see the future, and if that sounds like a Tom Cruise movie, that is because it is.    --Philip K. Dick

name: White Teeth
descip: At the center of this invigorating novel are two unlikely friends, Archie Jones and Samad Iqbal. Hapless veterans of World War II, Archie and Samad and their families become agents of England's irrevocable transformation.    --Zadie Smith

name: The Golden Notebook
descip: The Golden Notebook is the story of writer Anna Wulf, the four notebooks in which she records her life, and her attempt to tie them together in a fifth, gold-coloured notebook.

name: The Heart of the Matter
descip: The book follows Henry Scobie, a British police officer in west Africa, as he struggles with the guilt of infidelity.    --Graham Greene

name: Pale Fire
descip: An ingeniously constructed parody of detective fiction and learned commentary.   --Vladimir Nabokov.

name: The Moviegoer
descip: An ingeniously constructed parody of detective fiction and learned commentary, Pale Fire offers a cornucopia of deceptive pleasures .  --Vladimir Nabokov

name: Money
descip: The story of John Self and his insatiable appetite for money, alcohol, fast food, drugs, pornography, and more, Money is ceaselessly inventive and thrillingly savage; a tale of life lived without restraint, of money and the disasters it can precipitate.    --Martin Louis Amis

name: Deliverance
descip: the novel tells the story of four Atlanta suburbanites on a back-to-nature canoe trip that turns into a terrifying test of survival.    --James Dickey

name: The Sot-Weed Factor
descip: The Sot-Weed Factor is widely considered the first and greatest postmodern novel. In a satirical romp through America’s colonial history.    --John Barth

name: The Adventures of Augie March
descip: It features the eponymous Augie March, who grows up during the Great Depression.    -- Saul Bellow,

name: The Berlin Stories
descip: The two novells are set in Berlin in 1931, just as Adolf Hitler was moving into power. Berlin is portrayed by Isherwood during this transitional period of cafes and quaint avenues, grotesque nightlife and dreamers, and powerful mobs and millionaires.    --Christopher Isherwood

name: A Death in the Family
descip: Religion is probably the most notable topic of exploration in A Death in the Family. It is the greatest cause of discussion and strife within both the nuclear family of Mary, Jay, Rufus, and little Catherine, and in Mary's extended family.  --James Rufus Agee

name: Appointment in Samarra
descip: Appointment in Samarra, occur over just three days in the life of the protagonist, Julian English. Julian commits three impulsive acts that lead to his downfall and eventual suicide.    --John O'Hara
